ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I personally took this course without having as strong of a background in Machine Learning theory/Multivariable calculus (took in HS and forgot some stuff) and linear algebra. The PSETs were manageable, but I personally found it hard to keep up in class with the intense mathematics that occurred.
Variational inference, sampling, proof techniques for optimization such as KL divergence.

This course gives an in-depth overview of the central theoretical concepts underpinning probabilistic generative models, which is a highly relevant field in artificial intelligence and machine learning. Andre's lecturing style maintains a delicate balance between clarity and thoroughness, which I greatly appreciated.
This course enhanced my understanding of statistics, probability theory, and optimization and my knowledge of differentiable manifolds.
The general probabilistic machine learning skills including optimization and modeling. Together with many useful mathematical skills
Got a much more rigorous understanding of machine learning algorithms and probability theory. Good general math and coding practice
Review many of the previous probability knowledge and learn a lot of new things in ML and Statistics.
By taking this course, I understood the mathematical aspects of machine learning better.
Familiarity with multivariate distributions, optimization, generative models

The theory of linear regression, gradient flow/descent, Bayesian inference, approx. inference, logistic regression, Laplace approximation, divergences between distributions, expectation propagation, variational inference, rejection sampling, Gibbs sampling, MCMC methods like Metropolis Random Walk and Metropolis-Hastings, Metropolis-adjusted Langevin algorithm, Wasserstein distance, Langevin algorithm, Langevin dynamics, Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process, coupling, alpha-SC, proximal sampling, forward and reverse SDEs, convergence analysis, denoising diffusion, score-based generative modeling.
bayesian inference, sampling, diffusion models

I learned mainly about continuous-time sampling and machine learning involved in score-based generative diffusion models. The topics included but were not limited to Langevin dynamics, O-U process, Bayesian linear regression, stochastic differential equations, and generative modeling.
A great intro to PML
probabilistic machine learning algorithms

I learned about the topic of probabilistic sampling and optimization, up through the basics of score-based generative modeling and the use of SDEs for sampling from distributions. We also covered Bayesian inference and helpful probability concepts such as divergences.

Bayesian Statistics, optimization, posterior analysis, several information theoretic concepts, sampling using Monte Carlos and confidence to take my understanding in such modellings to my work in Economics

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It would be better if the lecture recording can be provided.
too much workload
The strengths of this course is its subject and the fact that it is taught from a specialist on the subject.
Very rigorous, very time consuming, not many weaknesses, just sometimes was a bit much in terms of workload

Strength:
The instructor uses handwriting to teach the class, which is clear.

Strengths: Lectures from Andre were solid, great at stopping to answer simple questions and was flexible with assignment deadlines. Teaching staff made an effort to host Friday sections to cover extra topics for our enrichment. Weaknesses: never got back grades/feedback for project proposal and guidelines surrounding project were a bit unclear though the Edstem did help to mitigate it somewhat.
very good lectures. The professor prepared very well and is so nice to answer any questions

Andre is extremely knowledgeable in the subject, as it is his main research area of interest. He has written very interesting papers on some of the topics we discussed in class. Moreover, he comes to lectures very well-prepared and answers any questions that students might have, either during or after the lecture (in particular, he almost always stays around after class to address students' questions and devotes as much as an hour or more after class for such private QnA times). Perhaps one weakness of the class is that it is sometimes not easy to follow the entire flow of the course; personally, I was able to digest materials in each lecture, but the relationships between lectures were often lost amid the details of mathematical derivation. My advice for future prospective students would be to take note of the broader picture as they progress throughout the semester.
Lighten the load of the problem sets very slightly - the extra work required of grad students was substantial
I think the concepts can be more clearly explained.

strengths
has notable strengths in terms of the professors' expertise, clarity, and organization. 
TAs are very knowledgeable and helpful as well, and offer valuable assistance. 
the materials provided are well-structured, progressively moving from fundamental to advanced topics (and ultimately to a very useful application). 
the problem sets are very helpful and very closely aligned with the course content

how could it be improved
It could adhere more closely to the syllabus (or adjust the syllabus accordingly).

The course was well-organized and easy to follow the progression from class to class. The concepts are part of a new and emerging field and Professor Wibisono did an excellent job of teaching very recently published mathematics and theoretical results from this area of computer science, as well as providing citations to the papers referenced in lecture. However, I wish that we had had an extra week or so in the class to fully connect the theoretical techniques and convergence bounds proven in class to their use in empirical systems for generative modeling: I enjoyed getting a taste of the sorts of theoretical results proven in this field, but am very interested in how fast these theorems can be applied and made useful in practice.

Strength : The assignments really helped understand the mathematics and the concept behind the jargon. Well designed and helpful.
Weakness: I think the course introduction did not properly indicate what the learning outcomes of the class were going to be.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: fun
Yes,
For anybody interested in the theory behind probabilistic models and sampling algorithms in statistics and machine learning, definitely give this course a go.
The course was genuinely eye-opening covering a very interesting and currently active area of research
Yes, but only for those who with very good math and probabilistic background.
If you want a better understanding of sampling algorithms, probability theory, convex optimization, and ML in general, you need to take this class. Its required for CS I think

I would recommend this course if you have a strong math background (S&DS 241/242, MATH 225 at least) and some machine learning courses. It feels better suited towards graduate students working on theoretical ML than undergrads with an interest in ML

Don't be fooled, this is a high-level stats/math class, not a CS class. I would recommend if you're looking to refresh your knowledge of and sharpen your quantitative stats skills, and if you're interested in learning various topics in machine learning from a theoretical, not application, lens. Your foundation in statistical and probability theory has to be solid (e.g. from S&DS 241/242) to understand the lectures, and a good deal of multivariate calculus was on the p-sets as well. P-sets were mostly computational / theoretical though the later p-sets required some coding to plot some graphs, but definitely no intensive coding whatsoever, all math/stats-flavored p-sets. Also, a lot of topics covered were niche and research-specific. We cover results as recent as 2022-2023 which was interesting and made our material feel relevant but also everything was completely theoretical so not relevant for those probably not interested in theoretical ML research. I also have a math and stats background so I enjoyed the class and didn't find the workload to be heavy.
Yes

I would strongly recommend this course to any student, especially if they have an interest in optimization and sampling. I took this course to better understand diffusion models, and I came out of this course a lot more aware of the machinery behind state-of-the-art generative models, such as DALLE or Stable Diffusion. The mathematics involved is difficult but rewarding to understand, and although the lectures can be dense, the bi-weekly problem sets are extremely reasonable. The course is really focused on helping students learn instead of evaluating or testing students' knowledge, which I found to be very conducive for my own learning (you can really focus on studying instead of worrying or stressing about exams).
Yes, if you are serious about learning about the theory of machine learning, this course is a complete essential.
Yes. The course is good for getting to know sampling.

I would highly recommend this course to students who have an interest in diffusion generative model and are willing to invest the time. 
It comprehensively introduces the fundamental theory and associated concepts and algorithms of diffusion generative models.
The course provides a well-structured path, providing essential tools and concepts necessary for understanding diffusion generative models, along with in-depth proofs. 
Overall, it is a valuable learning experience for those willing to dive into this topic.

I would recommend this course to another student, but I would recommend future students weight the listed prerequisites when deciding whether to take the course. The listed prerequisites are less in depth and stringent than I think may be required for most students, and it would be helpful for students to keep in mind that it is helpful to have some background in optimization. However, if one does not meet all the prerequisites, the professor still did a good job of briefly reviewing concepts as they become relevant in lecture.
if they have proper mathematical background, yes!!!
